awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track B:  Strengthening community paramedicine services through action research
awd_abstract_narration:
Community paramedicine programs are designed to provide expedited and customized care to underserved and often vulnerable populations seeking repeat assistance through emergency 9-1-1 services. While evaluations show that these programs are effective at reducing use of emergency services and saving cities money, knowledge of how successful these programs are at improving the quality of life for the clients they serve and whether they serve the community equitably is limited. This participatory action research project explores the perspectives of San Francisco Fire Department Community Paramedicine Division’s vulnerable clients and the paramedicine staff. The goals in Stage 1 are to identify indicators of success as defined by clients and staff and develop a method to meaningfully measure progress toward successful outcomes. The project aims to consolidate data from several distinct community paramedicine programs to better understand the client population. Insights from this project will be used to develop, pilot, and evaluate interventions to improve effectiveness and equitable delivery of community paramedicine services in San Francisco and other communities across the United States. 

The vision for this project is to strengthen community paramedicine’s work to improve the quality of life and resilience of residents of San Francisco who rely heavily on emergency services. Existing metrics to evaluate community paramedicine programs focus only on cost-savings and efficiencies and not on the experiences of vulnerable clients and community paramedics. The research team will be measuring success at the individual- and community-level, tracking how equitably these programs are being delivered, and developing strategies to reduce burnout and moral injury among community paramedics. The Stage 1 activities are guided by three core questions: 1) how do community paramedicine staff, clients, and municipal stakeholders define success for community paramedicine programs?; 2) what are useful metrics to measure equitable delivery of community paramedicine programs and what data should be routinely collected to assess these metrics?; and 3) what interventions could improve the coordination, design, equitable delivery, and/or efficiency of community paramedicine services? The Stage 2 pilot will test best practices that could be scaled and adopted by other community paramedicine programs that share the goal of serving vulnerable populations.

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track B. Bridging the gap between essential resources and services & community needs—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SAN JOSE STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION

por.por_cntn:
Community Paramedicine (CP), also known as mobile integrated health, is an approach to providing customized care to community members and alleviating strain on emergency services. In San Francisco, community paramedics work on several street teams responding to residents experiencing homelessness, drug overdoses, and crises related to mental health or substance abuse.

 

This planning grant was a collaboration between San José State University researchers and the San Francisco Fire Department (SFFD) CP Division and focused on two major challenges facing community paramedicine, emergency medical services, and prehospital care. The first challenge is equity. Work to understand and mitigate disparities within EMS and CP practice is significantly behind other aspects of the healthcare system. As these programs develop and expand, it is critical to build equity into the design and implementation of these programs and share best practices through the field in order to improve outcomes for the vulnerable populations served. The second challenge is that community paramedics are exposed to an entirely different set of moral dilemmas and pressures due to expanding the scope of work for paramedics beyond emergency medical care and hospital transport to supporting clients experiencing homelessness, addiction, and serious mental illness in the community. This work puts community paramedics at risk of moral injury - a mental health injury stemming from perceived transgression of deeply held moral values. Moral injury can not only harm community paramedics, but impedes their ability to serve clients and can create structural challenges for municipalities, as moral injury is associated with burnout and attrition.

 

During the Stage 1 Planning Grant, researchers met with CP and SFFD leadership over 20 times. We conducted six two-hour focus groups with CP division members exploring how members view success of programs, points of frustration and satisfaction, understanding of equity, and experiences of moral distress and injury. We thematically analyzed the data and reported our findings back to members of the CP division. We also separately discussed findings with CP leadership to develop a shared understanding of the findings. From our analysis of focus group responses, we developed a working conceptual model for moral injury in CP practice to demonstrate how exposure to potentially morally injurious events (PMIEs) experienced during work can lead to moral distress, or more severe moral injury. The focus groups also yielded valuable insights into solutions to the problems experienced by clients and CP members. To harness the insights from these focus groups for the development of our Stage 2 pilot proposal, SJSU investigators developed a participatory brainstorming activity for CP members to generate new ideas, comment on previously suggested ideas, and vote up/down these proposed solutions to the challenges identified.

 

We also examined de-identified encounter log data from over 10,000 Street Response Team calls and analyzed these records for data quality and to identify a starting point for tracking equity in service delivery. We found extensive and systematic missingness in demographic data. In the focus groups, CP members expressed discomfort with collecting these data, noting that it felt transactional and often inappropriate, and that the narrow options for classification did not match client’s reality. We met with the SFFD Chief of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion to better understand the equity context in the organization and developed a multi-prong approach to strengthen data equity for our Stage 2 pilot proposal.

 

Investigators also held multiple conversations with RAMS peer-based services and conducted a focus group with RAMS peer supervisors who work with CP on the street response teams. RAMS has over a decade of experience in peer-based services, providing certification and training to individuals who have personal lived experience with mental health and/or substance use challenges to become peer counselors. Recognizing the value of the unique peer specialist perspective, we expanded the collaborative team for our Stage 2 proposal to include RAMS. We also brought on Co-PI Dr. Shira Maguen, who is an expert in moral injury. Dr. Maguen recently developed and validated a scale to assess moral distress and injury in civilian populations, including among first responders (the Moral Injury and Distress Scale, MIDS), which will be utilized in Stage 2 to provide the first quantitative assessment of moral injury and moral distress among community paramedics.

 

The intellectual merit of this planning grant includes the development of a conceptual model for moral injury in community paramedicine and emergency medical services and an initial equity analysis of community paramedicine data that can guide further efforts to understand, monitor, and improve equity. This work will be expanded during the Stage 2 award. Ultimately, the broader impacts of this project include improved quality of life for first responders and vulnerable residents, progress towards improving equity, and a model for successful transdisciplinary participatory action research to address critical problems.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2023
Modified by: Miranda   Worthen
